It may please yo

whiche yo
w
willed in yo
r

e 23 of May
to be proposed to
e
states
, and their answear unto
it. Accordingly as they have signified, I
can not any way perceave, that ether
e states

autorised
S
t
Aldegonde
, to make that motion to
e
Kinge
. Uppon
e receat of their answear,
M
r
Wilkes
arrived at
e
Hage
, by whome I am in-
formed, that her
Ma
tie
doth not finde that mater
so cleere, as
e advertisment was given, and ther-
fore is not willing, to have it spoken of. Howbeit,
before yo
r
L. letter came hither, as I signified in
my last, it was a constant speeche among many,
and so it is yet, that
Justinus
e Viceadmiral of
Zeland
, was to deale w
t
e King to some suche
purpose. And whether it be true, or otherwise,
ether of him, or of S
t
Aldegonde, by meanes of this
advertisment, they are so made afraide in this place,
of her Ma
ties
vigilance in those causes, as I thinke
hereafter, they will not easely enter into suche kinde
of practises. M
r
Wilkes hath made
me acquainted w
t
his Instructions, and I have
noted unto him divers principal pointes, to w
ch
I could wishe that her Ma
tie
had bin privy, before
his comming from home. Nevertheles, as they are,
I will doe my best endevo
r
, to cotnent her Ma
tie
:
and if the states be not bent, to some other innovation
of their state
s
, there may be some hope of a good
reformac
o
n. For that point, concerning
a General to be sent, for
e

of
the

Ma
tie
yo
r
L. knoweth. But for ought I can per-
ceave, the great dislike w
ch
they have conceaved
heretofore of Inglishe Generals hath bin suche, and
nowe the affection of this people towardes
Count

Maurice is so great, besides
e proofes whiche he she-
weth of his valewe and sufficiencie, as I see no like-
lihoode, that they will yelde to any governo
r
above
him: being already governo
r
of fower of these Pro-
vinces. And under humble correction to say my
opinion, besides that it will drawe her Hig
nes
to a
further charge, I can not imagine that
e affaires
of these contreis; will take a better course by that
meanes. For if Count Maurice would keepe a good
correspondence w
t
her Ma
tie
wherto I have not found
by his dealing that he is greatly inclined, I see
not, all thinges considered, howe her Ma
tie
could
choose a better Lieutenant. That publike
declaration, w
ch
M
r
Wilkes hath brought, signed by
her Ma
tie
against
e mutins of these contreis, be-
cause it hath bin shewed
M
r
Ortell
, and is noti-
fied heere already, I knowe not what to say unto
it. Otherwise I should have thought it my duty, to
put her Ma
tie
in remembrance, that according to for-
mer promises, w
ch
these men have made, as I thinke
M
r
Caron
can calle to minde, there might also have
passed a graunt from them, of a general Obliance
of all maters, wherof
e said parties are accused.
Whiche I make no dout, but they would have granted
very willingly, if it had bin stoode uppon, and I
doe wishe M
r
Wilkes to urge it as yet. For there
are many among those pretended mutins, that are
deepely wronged, as her Ma
tie
hath often caused to
be signified heere unto them. It may happely
seeme a great deale better, that a fewe should
smarte,
then
that
e defense of suche persons should
make a disunion between her Ma
tie
and these
Provinces. But
e truth is, thoughe
e parties na-
med heere, are but fewe, yet their frindes and
welf
welwillers, and other like affected are many,
fol.178r
Belgia 1590: June
And her Ma
tie
hereafter, uppon any occasion, as
there may be many ministred, should have neede of
any frindes, to take her part in these contreis, I knowe
not whether this declaration will not sticke in their
stomakes. It is a mater that hath slept heere a long
time, so as we did beleve, it was not respected.
And I can not but mervell, at whose requisition
it hath bin revived, not perceaving any way that
it proceedeth from
e states. Because these are
two pointes of special importance, I thought to signi-
fie my opini
o
, w
ch
I doe not doubt but yo
r
L. will
alwaies accept. It is her Ma
ties
plea-
sure in her letter to
e states, that I should joine
w
t
M
r
Wilkes in maneging these affaires; but
I have no letter of warrant to my self, nether from
her Hig
nes
nor from my
LL of
e Councel
. I beseeche
yo
r
L. to consider howe muche it doth behove me
in maters of suche moment, to have somwhat to shew,
for mine owne discharge. I have hitherto sustened
many bruites of thwarte proceedinges in this place,
and all in respect of
e sharpe messages, w
ch
it hath
pleased her Ma
tie
and my LL of
e Councel to
give me in charge to deliver to
e states. And if
nowe at last in some sort, I might ether have bin
deputed, or jointly committed for proposing some
gratefull maters, it would have bin both a comfort
and a credit unto me, and while my service is
used, a very great furtherance to her Ma
ties
pu
purposes. For thoughe there were mater of dislike
between me and some heere, in respect of
e forsaid
propositions, yet it never came to suche termes, but
that had I knowen her Ma
ties
pleasure to yelde so
farre in many thinges, as I doe at this present,
being heere in place, and knowing those courses w
ch
are
to be held w
t
most of them, I doe not dout but by
fol.178v
Belgia: 1590: June:
degrees I should have brought all thinges to a better
passe, then I feare we shall be able uppon this sod-
daine proposal. At my first comming hither, I doe
assure yo
r
L. a third part of those causes, that were
handled heere in councel, was mater of complaint
against
e disorders of her Ma
ties
subjects. Howbeit
at this present, we heare so seeldome of any thing,
as I thinke it unpossible for any straunge nation to
serve more quietly among them. What continuall
care I have taken, and what good meanes I have used,
to effect this good usage and liking on bothe sides
there is not one of this Councel, but will witnes
it, and so will those that commaund for her Ma
tie
.
I protest unto yo
r
L. I have written this muche
most unwillingly, as more desirous to have had it
acknowledged by
e events of thinges, then by
mine owne declaration. But I have lost a great
testimony for my self in
M
r
Secretary Walsingham
who as well by my letters, as by other informac
o
ns,
might perceave my proceedinges. and nowe, yo
r
L. excepted, I am utterly uncertaine whether
any honorable personage be acquainted w
t
my
astions
actions. were it not that I had reposed my trust
in yo
r
L. wisdome and goodnes towardes me, I
would not use this forme of stile in writing to yo
r
L.
But I am somwhat secure in that regard, and
therfore beseeche yo
w
most humbly to continew me
still in a gratious opinion both of her Ma
tie
and of
my LL., and not any longer in ether, then my care-
full service shall deserve it. It is ad-
vertised hither from sundrie places, that
Richardot
hath bin a sutor to
e
Pope
, in
e
King of Spaines
behalf, to graunt to these contreis, by way of
dispensation, freedome of religion.
And
I can
not ghesse, whether it be so intended in dede, or
it be but a practise for the time, to putte bees in

e headdes of this people, ether thereby to sturre
some dissention among them, or to procure some
other disturbance in their proceedinges. Nevertheles
I see no likelihoode of any good he shall doe by
suche offers. For whatsoever is heere pretended,
I doe not commonly see them so fervent in religion,
as that they will preferre it above
e profitte of
their traffique. And as for
Holland
and Zeland,
the gentlemen excepted, whiche live by their re-
venues,
e common marchants and artisans, are
almost all of them richer by these warres, at
lest by
e doubble, then they were in time of peace,
or are like to be heereafter, if
Brabant
,
Flan-
ders
, and other Provinces, should participat in
their traffique. This day M
r
Wilkes had his
audience, whiche had no mater to be advertised,
consisting wholy of complements.
And so I take
my humble leave. Junij 13. 90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
